pullRequest.body:
Prove two characterizations of commutative semirings R whose prime spectra have discrete topology:

+ R has finitely many prime ideals, and every prime ideal is maximal;

+ R has finitely many maximal ideals, the intersection of which (= Jacobson radical) is contained in (and therefore equal to) the nilradical.

From the first characterization it is easy to show the spectrum of an Artinian ring has discrete topology, but Artinian doesn't currently import PrimeSpectrum.

Also show that if R is a commutative ring and Spec R has discrete topology, then the canonical RingHom from R to the product of localizations at maximal ideals (which is always injective) is an isomorphism. This is not a characterization, because it is satisfied by every local ring. (But it's a characterization if we replace "maximal" by "prime".)

For this purpose we prove that, if a basic open D(f) in Spec R is a singleton {p}, then localization away from f is the same as localization at p. A key fact used is that if an ideal in a commutative semiring is disjoint from a submonoid, then there exists a maximal such ideal containing the ideal, and any maximal such ideal is prime.

Also upgrade `exists_idempotent_basicOpen_eq_of_isClopen` to `existsUnique`.

---

Add Stacks tags to work done by @erdOne in #14372 and #18394.

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by erdOne.

I discovered [TopologicalSpace.Clopens](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Sets/Closeds.html#TopologicalSpace.Clopens) so I switched to use it in [this branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/DiscreteTopology_PrimeSpectrum...DiscreteTopology_PrimeSpectrum++?expand=1), and added more lemmas around `isIdempotentElemEquivClopens`.
I can merge them now or include them in a subsequent PR, which will show `toLocalizationIsPrime_surjective` is a characterization of comm. rings with discrete spectra.

> I discovered [TopologicalSpace.Clopens](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Sets/Closeds.html#TopologicalSpace.Clopens) so I switched to use it in [this branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/DiscreteTopology_PrimeSpectrum...DiscreteTopology_PrimeSpectrum++?expand=1), and added more lemmas around `isIdempotentElemEquivClopens`. I can merge them now or include them in a subsequent PR, which will show `toLocalizationIsPrime_surjective` is a characterization of comm. rings with discrete spectra.

Yes, I think it is better to use `TopologicalSpace.Clopens` when it makes sense.

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!
bors r+

I think I have a different proof of the main result (isomorphism with product of localizations) that works for semirings, which of course can't use subtraction (as in R/(1-e)R) and the CRT and must make use some form  of the fact that the structure sheaf still works over (comm.) semirings. This will make most lemmas in this PR unnecessary to prove the main result, but I think they're good by themselves.

The result I'll need is essentially some form of [AlgebraicGeometry.StructureSheaf.toBasicOpen_surjective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/StructureSheaf.html#AlgebraicGeometry.StructureSheaf.toBasicOpen_surjective) and the preceding lemma, but I don't need to cover an arbitrary basic open, only the whole spectrum. I have no reason to doubt the proofs work over semirings, but the whole file assumes CommRing. Therefore (also to not import this advanced file) I won't directly use these two theorems but will prove a version tailored to my use case, which is fortunately not too complicated.

Side comments: I think the basic opens of idempotents in some (comm.) semirings may not be closed, but I don't know about an example. And it looks like a fun undergraduate project to [compute](https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4224486/12932) $\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{N})$ in Lean.

I think I have a different proof of the main result (isomorphism with product of localizations) that works for semirings, which of course can't use subtraction (as in R/(1-e)R) and the CRT and must make use some form  of the fact that the structure sheaf still works over (comm.) semirings. This will make most lemmas in this PR unnecessary to prove the main result, but I think they're good by themselves.

The result I'll need is essentially some form of [AlgebraicGeometry.StructureSheaf.toBasicOpen_surjective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/StructureSheaf.html#AlgebraicGeometry.StructureSheaf.toBasicOpen_surjective) and the preceding lemma, but I don't need to cover an arbitrary basic open, only the whole spectrum. I have no reason to doubt the proofs work over semirings, but the whole file assumes CommRing. Therefore (also to not import this advanced file) I won't directly use these two theorems but will prove a version tailored to my use case, which is fortunately not too complicated.

Side comments: I think the basic opens of idempotents in some (comm.) semirings may not be closed, but I don't know about an example. And it looks like a fun undergraduate project to [compute](https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4224486/12932) $\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{N})$ in Lean.
